review.title: The Manifold of Human Emotions
review.abstract: Sentiment analysis predicts the presence of positive or negative emotions in a text document. In this paper, we consider higher dimensional extensions of the sentiment concept, which represent a richer set of human emotions. Our approach goes beyond previous work in that our model contains a continuous manifold rather than a finite set of human emotions. We investigate the resulting model, compare it to psychological observations, and explore its predictive capabilities.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: An alternative that has attracted some researchers in recent years is the construction of a finite collection of emotions and the adjustment of a predictive model for each emotion (see for example [1]). There are several significant difficulties with the above approach. Firstly, it is difficult to grasp a complex statistical relationship between a large number of binary variables (which represent emotions) and a high-dimensional vector (which represent the document). Furthermore, it is difficult to imagine a reliable process for compiling a finite list of all possible human emotions. Finally, it is not clear how documents that express a particular emotion should be used. The use of labeled documents only in suitable models that predict their labels, ignores the relationship between emotions and is problematic for emotions with only a few comments. sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: We have used these optional annotations in the form of emoticons, which can be selected from a predefined list of possible emotions, or from a novel emotion specified by the author. We have searched 15,910,060 doc-1http: / / www.livejournal.com and selected 1,346,937 documents that feature the most popular 32 emotion labels (in terms of the number of documents included in annotations). In Figure 1, we compare our model with Watson and Tellegen's well-known psychological model. We make the following observations: First, the horizontal axis expresses a mood of polarity-like emotion; the left part shows emotions as accomplished, happy and excited, while the right part shows emotions as sad and depressed. This is in line with Watson and Tellegen's observations. Second, the vertical predictive axis expresses the level of mental engagement or energy level.

sections.heading: 4 Summary
sections.text: In this work, we introduced a continuous representation of human emotions Z and constructed a statistical model linking them to documents X and a discrete set of emotions Y. Our adapted model bears great similarities to models developed in the psychological literature based on human survey data. Recently, several attempts have been made to derive insights from social media or news data through mood predictions. It is likely that the current multivariate view of emotions will contribute to progress in these important and challenging tasks.
